proof:
Proof. For the first part, expand out the rhs using polymer weight definition,
$$ q^{n_c} \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = q^{n_c + |\Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)| - \sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} |V_G(\gamma)|} (e^\beta - 1)^{\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} e_G(\gamma)} $$
Disordered polymers of F are exactly the connected components on $(V_C, F)$, thus $|\Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)| = c(F)$, $\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} |V_G(\gamma)| = n_c$. Every in-edge of F is in a polymer and polymers of F do not overlap, thus also $\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} e_G(\gamma) = |F|$. Hence the the first part of the lemma follows.

Next, notice that any disordered polymer containing no edges has weight 1. So for any $\gamma = (\{v\}, \emptyset)$, the inequality in the lemma is trivial. So suppose $\gamma$ is a polymer with at least one edge. Then for any $F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}$ with $\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)$, let $F' := F \setminus E_G(\gamma)$ and note $F' \ne F$. The components of $(V_C, F')$ are exactly the components of $(V_C, F)$, except for the vertices of $\gamma$, that are in $\gamma$ in $(V_C, F)$, but in isolated vertices in $(V_C, F')$. Thus $w_C(F') = w_C(F)q^{|V_G(\gamma)|-1}(e^\beta-1)^{-e_G(\gamma)} = w_C(F)/w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)$.
Let $\Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}} \mid \gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)\}$. Then we can write
$$ \pi_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(\cdot)) = \frac{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} w_C(F)}{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}} w_C(F)} \le \frac{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} w_C(F)}{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} (w_C(F) + w_C(F'))} \le \frac{1}{1+1/w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} \le w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma). $$
